'''Zoomusicology''' is a field of [[musicology]] and [[zoology]] or more specifically, [[Animal communication|zoosemiotics]]. Zoomusicology is the study of the [[music]] of [[animal]]s, or rather the [[musical aspect]]s of [[sound]] or [[communication]] produced and received by animals.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Doolittle|first=Emily|last2=Gingras|first2=Bruno|date=October 2015|title=Zoomusicology|journal=Current Biology|volume=25|issue=19|pages=R819–R820|doi=10.1016/j.cub.2015.06.039|pmid=26439331|issn=0960-9822}}</ref>
Zoomusicology is a separate field from [[ethnomusicology]], the study of human music.
==Human interaction== {{further|Birds in music|Insects in music}}
Snowden and Teie created species-specific music and tested it on cotton-top tamarins, ''[[Cotton-top tamarin|Saguinus oedipus]]'' at the University of Wisconsin.<ref name="Biol. Lett.">{{cite journal|author1=Snowdon, C. T. and Teie, D.|title=Affective responses in tamarins elicited by species-specific music|journal=Biology Letters of the Royal Society B|date=2010|volume=6|issue=1|pages=30–32|doi=10.1098/rsbl.2009.0593|pmid=19726444|accessdate=20 July 2014|url=http://rsbl.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/early/2009/09/01/rsbl.2009.0593|pmc=2817256}}</ref> The results of this study, indicated that species-specific music was the most effective music to elicit a response.<ref name="Biol. Lett." /> There have also been cases where composers have performed with animals for example, David Rothenberg, is a musician who has created music with humpback whales, ''[[Humpback whale|Megaptera novaeangliae]].''<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.sibetrans.com/trans/articulo/97/to-wail-with-a-whale-anatomy-of-an-interspecies-duet|title=TRANS - Revista Transcultural de Música - Transcultural Music Review|website=www.sibetrans.com|language=es|access-date=2018-11-16}}</ref> Both of these examples are discussed in greater detail below.
Composers have evoked or imitated animal sounds in compositions including [[Jean-Philippe Rameau]]'s ''The Hen'' (1728), [[Camille Saint-Saëns]]'s ''Carnival of the Animals'' (1886), [[Olivier Messiaen]]'s ''Catalogue of the Birds'' (1956–58) and [[Pauline Oliveros]]'s ''El Relicario de los Animales'' (1977).<ref>{{Cite book|author=Von Gunden, Heidi|year=1983|title=The Music of Pauline Oliveros|isbn=978-0-8108-1600-8|page=133}}</ref> Other examples include [[Alan Hovhaness]]'s ''And God Created Great Whales'' (1970), [[George Crumb]]'s ''Vox Balaenae'' (Voice of the Whale) (1971) and [[Gabriel Pareyon]]'s ''Invention over the song of the [[Vireo atricapilla|Vireo atriccapillus]]'' (1999) and ''Kha Pijpichtli Kuikatl'' (2003). The Indian zoomusicologist, A. J. Mithra has composed music using bird, animal and [[frog sound]]s since 2008.<ref>"[http://www.indiasendangered.com/interview-a-j-mithra-making-music-with-animal-calls Interview: a j mithra, Making Music with Animal Calls]", ''IndiasEndangered.com''. "The only known zoo musicologist in India and the second in the world after [[Jim Fassett]] who was known to create similar music from animal sounds way back in 1955."</ref>
== Functions and effects of music on animals ==
=== Mammals === [[File:Saguinus_oedipus_(Linnaeus,_1758).jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Saguinus_oedipus_(Linnaeus,_1758).jpg|thumb|Saguinus oedipus (Linnaeus, 1758)]] Snowden and Teie performed an experiment on [[Cotton-top tamarin|Cotton-top tamarins, ''Saguinus oedipus'']], to determine if music would lead to behavioural changes, and whether music made by other species would elicit similar behavioural responses as the music of one’s own species. <ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|last=Snowdon|first=Charles T.|last2=Teie|first2=David|date=2010-02-23|title=Affective responses in tamarins elicited by species-specific music|url=http://rsbl.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/6/1/30|journal=Biology Letters|language=en|volume=6|issue=1|pages=30–32|doi=10.1098/rsbl.2009.0593|issn=1744-9561|pmc=2817256|pmid=19726444}}</ref> This experiment involved two separate categories of music - one was affiliation-based, the other was fear/threat-based music. Within the two categories, the experimenter varied whether the music was produced by [[Human|humans]] or tamarins.<ref name=":02" /> During the experiment, a baseline behaviour measurement was established, proceeded by the experimental condition, which was a piece of music that was played for 30 seconds. Following this, behaviour was analyzed for a total of 5 minutes. This analysis was made by an observer who was unaware of the true hypothesis of the experiment, and simply noted different behaviours which they had witnessed.<ref name=":02" /> The experimenters found that the Tamarins altered their behaviour specifically when listening to Tamarin music. For example, when music from the affiliation condition was played, the behavioural response of the tamarins involved a decrease in overall movement and an increase in both social and foraging behaviour.<ref name=":02" /> This contrasted the behaviour observed when the fear/threat based music was played. During this condition, the Tamarins were more likely to move around and show anxiety-based behaviour, as well as, an increase in social behaviour similar to that seen in the affiliation condition. It should also be noted that while the Tamarins did not show behavioural changes to human music as clearly as they did to their species-specific music, there was some behavioural change.<ref name=":02" /> The Tamarins showed decreased movement when listening to human fear/threat based music and a decrease in anxious behaviour when listening to human affiliation music. This experiment, demonstrates that music is capable of eliciting changes in the behaviour of animals, most especially when the music is species-specific. [[File:Baleine_à_bosse_et_son_baleineau_2.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Baleine_%C3%A0_bosse_et_son_baleineau_2.jpg|thumb|Baleine à bosse et son baleineau 2]] [[Humpback whale|Humpback whales, ''Megaptera novaeangliae'']], are capable of the production of complex songs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sibetrans.com/trans/articulo/97/to-wail-with-a-whale-anatomy-of-an-interspecies-duet|title=TRANS - Revista Transcultural de Música - Transcultural Music Review|website=www.sibetrans.com|language=es|access-date=2018-10-24}}</ref> These songs are amongst some of the longest measured in animals. Only male humpback whales perform these vocalizations; it was initially hypothesized that these songs may be a part of the [[sexual selection]] process. This point however, is unclear. It has been found that males only began their song after joining a group where pairs of mother and calf were present.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Smith|first=Joshua N.|last2=Goldizen|first2=Anne W.|last3=Dunlop|first3=Rebecca A.|last4=Noad|first4=Michael J.|date=2008-08|title=Songs of male humpback whales, Megaptera novaeangliae, are involved in intersexual interactions|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=76|issue=2|pages=467–477|doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2008.02.013|issn=0003-3472}}</ref> Although the reason behind this behaviour is uncertain, some have hypothesized that the songs produced by male humpback whales may be a part of escorting, or accompanying females. It should also be noted that singing can be a costly behaviour, because it can lead to more attention being drawn. In the humpback whales’ situation, their singing can attract other competing males.<ref name=":12" /> Yet, the singing behaviour continues and therefore, it is assumed that the songs are critical to the [[Courtship behavior|courtship behaviour]] of the humpback whales.
=== Birds === [[File:Song_Sparrow.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Song_Sparrow.jpg|thumb|Song Sparrow]] Perhaps the most well-known form of music found in non-human animals is [[birdsong]].<ref name=":22">{{Cite journal|last=Rothenberg|first=David|last2=Roeske|first2=Tina C.|last3=Voss|first3=Henning U.|last4=Naguib|first4=Marc|last5=Tchernichovski|first5=Ofer|date=2014-02|title=Investigation of musicality in birdsong|journal=Hearing Research|volume=308|pages=71–83|doi=10.1016/j.heares.2013.08.016|issn=0378-5955|pmc=3947120|pmid=24036130}}</ref> Birdsong is different from normal calls. For example, a call will usually simply function to communicate a direct message.<ref name=":22" /> For instance, a bird call could be used to direct attention that a predator is near. Meanwhile a song contains more repetition and usually will have distinct structure to it, with a specific beginning, middle, and end.<ref name=":22" /> In many species of [[Songbird|songbirds]], songs seem to be used both as a way to attract potential mates, as well as to mark and defend one's territory. It has been observed that young songbirds acquire their ability to produce song from imitation of adult birds.<ref name=":22" /> Interestingly enough, there seems to be a critical period for song learning. In one experiment, they compared birds raised in isolation, (this involved isolation from other birds as well as the vocalizations of other birds), with those raised in a colony, without these forms of isolation.<ref name=":22" /> Using an [[Functional magnetic resonance imaging|fMRI]] scan and the [[Blood-oxygen-level dependent imaging|blood oxygen level dependent]] (BOLD) as a measurement of brain activity, it was found that birds raised in the isolation condition did not appear to show a preference between their own songs and a repetitive song. Meanwhile colony-raised birds showed a stronger reaction to their own song being played back.<ref name=":22" />
=== '''Insects''' === [[File:Imago_O_furnacalis.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Imago_O_furnacalis.jpg|thumb|Imago O furnacalis]] One potential barrier in the study of zoomusicology is that there are some forms of music produced by various animals which humans are incapable of hearing.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Balenger|first=Susan L.|date=2015-07|title=Stridulated soft song by singing insects|url=https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0003347215001244|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=105|pages=275–280|doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2015.03.024|issn=0003-3472}}</ref> This music is very low in amplitude and is known as quiet song, whisper communication, or soft song.<ref name=":3" /> This low amplitude music has been shown in birds, as well as insects and is linked to behaviour. Moth species have been shown to have developed the ability to communicate using ultrasonic sounds, and this ability has transferred over to their production of soft songs. In the [[Ostrinia furnacalis|Asian corn borer moth, ''Ostrinia furnacalis'']], males produce an ultrasonic soft song to initiate courtship behaviour.<ref name=":3" /> The song that the male produces is so quiet that the female must be within a range of three centimeters in order to hear the song. In hearing the song, the female stays in one place and is completely still, this allows the male to initiate mating behaviour.<ref name=":3" /> The reason that the female remains still, is because this song sounds very similar to sounds that a bat would produce. The female therefore remains still in order to avoid potential [[predation]]. There is of course another added benefit to this soft song produced by the male Asian corn borer moth, and that is that the song is so quiet that it decreases the males’ predation risk.<ref name=":3" /> Although these soft songs are far less well-known to the general public, they are an important aspect of zoomusicology and the further understanding of [[animal behaviour]].
== Auditory enrichment and therapeutic effects of music on animals ==
=== Cows === In a study at the [[University of Leicester]], Liam MacKenzie and Adrian North found that playing music for [[Dairy cattle|dairy cows]] had an effect on the amount of milk that they produced.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.le.ac.uk/press/press/moosicstudy.html|title=Administration: 'Moosic Study' Reveals Way of Increasing Milk Yields [Psychology; Agriculture; Industry]|website=www.le.ac.uk|access-date=2018-11-19}}</ref> Over a nine-week period, dairy cows were exposed to fast (> 120 BPM), slow (< 100 BPM), and no music. Music was played for the cows 12 hours a day from 5 AM to 5 PM.<ref name=":0" /> The study found that cows exposed to slow music, like [[R.E.M.|REM]]'s '[[Everybody Hurts]]' or [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven]]'s '[[Symphony No. 6 (Beethoven)|Pastoral Symphony]],' produced 3% more milk than cows that were exposed to fast music, like [[Pumping on Your Stereo|Pumping on your Stereo]] by [[Supergrass]] and 'Size of a Cow' by [[The Wonder Stuff|Wonderstuff]].<ref name=":0" /> Bovine milk production has long been thought to be affected by exposure to music. Some farmers already expose their cows to music to aid in milk production.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://themilkingparlourblog.wordpress.com/2015/05/26/do-cows-like-music/|title=Do cows like music?|date=2015-05-26|work=the milking parlour blog|access-date=2018-11-19|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Dogs === Decreased stress levels have been observed in kennelled dogs that were exposed to Classical music, but rapid [[habituation]] was also observed.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Bowman|first=A.|last2=Dowell|first2=F.J.|last3=Evans|first3=N.P.|date=2017-03|title=‘The effect of different genres of music on the stress levels of kennelled dogs’|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.physbeh.2017.01.024|journal=Physiology & Behavior|volume=171|pages=207–215|doi=10.1016/j.physbeh.2017.01.024|issn=0031-9384}}</ref> In a 2017 follow up study, kennelled dogs were exposed to five different genres of music including [[Soft rock|Soft Rock]], [[Motown]], [[Pop music|Pop]], [[Reggae]], and [[Classical music|Classical]] in order to determine whether or not increased variety of music could reduce habituation.<ref name=":2" /> The study found the Heart Rate Variability, which indicates a decreased stress level, was significantly higher when the dogs were played Reggae and Soft Rock, but the other three genres had a similar but less pronounced effect. In addition, the dogs were much more likely to lie down rather than stand while the music was being played.<ref name=":2" /> The study suggested that the increased variety of music decreased habituation that was present when playing exclusively classical music, though the dogs responded best when exposed to Reggae and Soft Rock.<ref name=":2" />
==Zoomusicologists== Researchers in a wide range of fields including [[music]], [[semiotics]], [[philosophy]] and [[biology]] conduct zoomusicology research. This is due to the fact that the field of zoomusicology is so broad and reaches many disciplines. Musician and zoomusicologist Hollis Taylor has conducted an extensive study of the Pied Butcherbird, [[Pied butcherbird|Cracticus nigrogularis]] over the past 15 years, including interdisciplinary research with philosophers and scientists.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=TAYLOR|first=HOLLIS|date=March 2014|title=Whose Bird Is It? Messiaen's Transcriptions of Australian Songbirds|journal=Twentieth-Century Music|volume=11|issue=1|pages=63–100|doi=10.1017/s1478572213000194|issn=1478-5722}}</ref> Clarinetist, and philosopher [[David Rothenberg]] plays music with animals, and has written books on the relationship between bird, insect, and whale song and human music.<ref name=":1" /> Composer [[Emily Doolittle]] has written numerous pieces based on animal songs, and has published interdisciplinary music-science research on the hermit thrush<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Doolittle|first1=Emily|last2=Gingras|first2=Bruno|last3=Endres|first3=Dominik|last4=Fitch|first4=Tecumseh|title=Overtone-based pitch selection in hermit thrush song: Unexpected convergence with scale construction in human music|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|volume=111|issue=46|pages=16616–16621|doi=10.1073/pnas.1406023111|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/111/46/16616.short|pmid=25368163|pmc=4246323|date=2014-11-18}}</ref> and the musician wren.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Doolittle|first1=Emily|author2=Henrik Brumm|title=O Canto do Uirapuru|url=http://www.musicstudies.org/JIMSvol6issue1PRINT/Doolittle_JIMS_12060103.pdf}}</ref> Susan Belanger has also contributed to the field of zoomusicology, with her work on soft song in the asian corn borer moth, ''[[Ostrinia furnacalis]]'' and its relationship to the initiation of mating behaviour.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Balenger|first=Susan L.|date=2015-07|title=Stridulated soft song by singing insects|url=https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0003347215001244|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=105|pages=275–280|doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2015.03.024|issn=0003-3472}}</ref> Researcher Patricia Gray has examined the music that can be seen in whales and songbirds.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gray|first=Patricia M.|last2=Krause|first2=Bernie|last3=Atema|first3=Jelle|last4=Payne|first4=Roger|last5=Krumhansl|first5=Carol|last6=Baptista|first6=Luis|date=2001|title=The Music of Nature and the Nature of Music|journal=Science|volume=291|issue=5501|pages=52–54|jstor=3082167}}</ref> This list is by no means all encompassing, but simply lists some notable members of the zoomusicology research community.
